messageBody:
kk_oop wrote:

>
> Hi.
>
> In Java, we have a class MyClass that privately contains an ArrayList
> as an attribute called myList. We were looking for a way to enable a
> JUnit test case class to call MyClass methods, then check the state of
> myList.
>
> Here's a what we are considering:

[snip]

Giving us the code may have made it a bit easier to answer your
question. Nevertheless, here goes:

My short answer is that I think you are going around your elbow to
scratch your nose. If I understand you correctly your original class
looks something like this:

public class MyClass {
private final Collection myList;
public MyClass() {
myList = new ArrayList();
}
public void doSomethingWithMyList() {
// ... code ...
}
}

And your test case class looks something like:

public class MyClassTest extends TestCase {
public void testDoSomethingWithMyList() {
//... test code ...
myClass.doSomethingWithMyList();
}
}

After you call doSomethingWithMyList() you want to get hold of myList in order to assert for the side effects. Correct?

I assume that you don't find any need for having an accessor on MyClass for myList, but I would ask why do you think it would be such a bad thing? If you are concerned about some client of MyClass changing myList then you can make it read-only. So your accessor would look like:

public Collection myList() {
return Collections.unmodifiableCollection(myList);
}

Then in your TestCase you can call the accessor to get a read-only version of myList and do your asserts that way.

Example:
public class MyClass {

private final Collection myList;

public MyClass(Collection initialCollection) {
myList = new ArrayList(initialCollection);
}

public void duplicateEntries() {
myList.addAll(myList);
}

public Collection myList() {
return Collections.unmodifiableCollection(myList);
}
}

public class MyClassTest extends TestCase {
public void testDoSomethingWithMyList() {
Collection initialCollection = Arrays.asList(new String[] {"a", "b"});
MyClass myClass = new MyClass(initialCollection);
assertEquals(initialCollection, myClass.myList());

myClass.duplicateEntries();
Collection expectedCollection = new ArrayList(initialCollection);
expectedCollection.addAll(initialCollection);
assertEquals(expectedCollection, myClass.myList());
}
}

--
